description: Coined by Thomas Graham in the mid 19th century as a clipping of gelatin, from French gélatine, from Italian gelatina, diminutive form of gelata (“iced”), from Latin gelata, past participle of gelo (“to freeze”), from gelu (“frost”), from Proto-Indo-European *gel- (“cold”)

entries.meaning: A semi-solid to almost solid colloid of a solid and a liquid, such as jelly, cheese or opal.
Any gel intended for a particular cosmetic use, such as for styling the hair.

verbs.description: gel (third-person singular simple present gels, present participle gelling, simple past and past participle gelled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To apply (cosmetic) gel to (the hair, etc).

examples: He was a nice guy, and I got on OK with his friends, but the two of us never really gelled.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figurative) To come together to form something; to cohere.
examples: We put our ideas together and they eventually gelled into a saleable product.

description: Imitative of upper-class British pronunciation of girl.
